Functional suitability.description: degree to which a product or system provides functions that meet stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions

Reliability.description: degree to which a system, product or component performs specified functions under specified conditions for a specified period

Performance efficiency.description: performance relative to the amount of resources used under stated conditions

Usability.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals with effectiveness, efficiency and satisfaction in a specified context of use

Maintainability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be modified by the intended maintainers

Security.description: degree to which a product or system protects information and data so that persons or other products or systems have the degree of data access appropriate to their types and levels of authorization

Compatibility.description: degree to which a product, system or component can exchange information with other products, systems or components, and/or perform its required functions, while sharing the same hardware or software environment

Portability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a system, product or component can be transferred from one hardware, software or other operational or usage environment to another

Supplier.description: Description about anyone who provides goods or services to a company or individuals.

Cost.description: Denotes the amount of money that a company spends on the creation or production of goods or services.

Product.description: Description about any article or substance that is manufactured or refined for sale.

Functional appropriateness.description: degree to which the functions facilitate the accomplishment of specified tasks and objectives

Functional completeness.description: degree to which the set of functions covers all the specified tasks and user objectives

Functional correctness.description: degree to which a product or system provides the correct results with the needed degree of precision

Maturity.description: degree to which a system, product or component meets needs for reliability under normal operation

Availability.description: degree to which a system, product or component is operational and accessible when required for use

Fault tolerance.description: degree to which a system, product or component operates as intended despite the presence of hardware or software faults

Recoverability.description: degree to which, in the event of an interruption or a failure, a product or system can recover the data directly affected and re-establish the desired state of the system

Time behavior.description: degree to which the response and processing times and throughput rates of a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements

Resource utilization.description: degree to which the amounts and types of resources used by a product or system, when performing its functions, meet requirements

Capacity.description: degree to which the maximum limits of a product or system parameter meet requirements

Appropriateness recognizability.description: degree to which users can recognize whether a product or system is appropriate for their needs

Learnability.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by specified users to achieve specified goals of learning to use the product or system with effectiveness, efficiency, freedom from risk and satisfaction in a specified context of use

Operability.description: degree to which a product or system has attributes that make it easy to operate and control

User error protection.description: degree to which a system protects users against making errors

User interface aesthetics.description: degree to which a user interface enables pleasing and satisfying interaction for the user

Accessibility.description: degree to which a product or system can be used by people with the widest range of characteristics and capabilities to achieve a specified goal in a specified context of use

Modularity.description: degree to which a system or computer program is composed of discrete components such that a change to one component has minimal impact on other components

Reusability.description: degree to which an asset can be used in more than one system, or in building other assets

Analyzability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which it is possible to assess the impact on a product or system of an intended change to one or more of its parts, or to diagnose a product for deficiencies or causes of failures, or to identify parts to be modified

Modifiability.description: degree to which a product or system can be effectively and efficiently modified without introducing defects or degrading existing product quality

Testability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which test criteria can be established for a system, product or component and tests can be performed to determine whether those criteria have been met

Confidentiality.description: degree to which a product or system ensures that data are accessible only to those authorized to have access

Integrity.description: degree to which a system, product or component prevents unauthorized access to, or modification of, computer programs or data

Non-repudiation.description: degree to which actions or events can be proven to have taken place, so that the events or actions cannot be repudiated later

Accountability.description: degree to which the actions of an entity can be traced uniquely to the entity

Authenticity.description: degree to which the identity of a subject or resource can be proved to be the one claimed

Co-existence.description: degree to which a product can perform its required functions efficiently while sharing a common environment and resources with other products, without detrimental impact on any other product

Interoperability.description: degree to which two or more systems, products or components can exchange information and use the information that has been exchanged

Adaptability.description: degree to which a product or system can effectively and efficiently be adapted for different or evolving hardware, software or other operational or usage environments

Installability.description: degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be successfully installed and/or uninstalled in a specified environment

Replaceability.description: degree to which a product can replace another specified software product for the same purpose in the same environment

Organizational structure.description: Description of the organizational structure of the supplier company.

Positioning and Strength.description: Description of the position of the supplier company in the market.

Reputation.description: Capability of the supplier to perform similar projects based on past experiences and certifications.

Services Offered.description: Description of the services offered by the supplier.

Support.description: Description of the support mechanisms offered by the supplier.

Licensing Schema.description: Description of the COTS component licensing options.

Licensing Costs.description: Detail of the costs for the different licensing options

Platform Cost.description: Estimation of the cost for the required production platform

Implementation Cost.description: Estimation of implementation costs based on similar past experiences.

Network Cost.description: Estimation of additional cost for network operation.

Stability.description: Attributes of the product that bear on the stability of the product.

Ownership.description: Attributes in relation to the intellectual property rights.

Deliverables.description: Detail of the out of the box and post implementation deliverables.

Parameterization / Customization.description: Attributes in relation to the initial effort required for the product to operate.

Guarantees.description: Detail of the guarantees provided over the product.

Node.js.description: A JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine, used for building scalable server-side applications.

Java.description: A high-level, object-oriented programming language widely used for developing cross-platform applications in various environments, especially enterprise systems.

C#.description: A multi-paradigm programming language developed by Microsoft for building Windows applications, web services, and cloud-based applications within the .NET framework.

Python.description: A versatile, high-level programming language known for its readability and applicability across a wide range of domains, from web development to data science.

F#.description: A functional-first language for .NET, designed with immutability and type safety in mind, often used for data processing and scientific applications.

JavaScript.description: A scripting language primarily used for adding interactivity to web pages and for building web applications, both on the client and server sides.

PowerShell.description: A task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft that includes a command-line shell and a scripting language.

Bash.description: A Unix shell and command language widely used for scripting and automating tasks on Linux and macOS systems.

PHP.description: A server-side scripting language originally designed for web development, widely used for generating dynamic web pages.

Window Scripting.description: A scripting environment for automating tasks on Windows operating systems, typically using VBScript or JScript.

Swift.description: A modern, powerful programming language for iOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS development, known for its performance and safety features.

Ruby.description: A dynamic, open-source programming language focused on simplicity and productivity, commonly used for web development.

.Net.description: A software development framework from Microsoft that provides a programming environment for building and running applications on Windows.

Go.description: A statically typed, compiled programming language developed by Google, known for its efficiency, scalability, and ease of use in concurrent applications.

Scala.description: A language combining object-oriented and functional programming paradigms, running on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), often used in big data and backend development.

Custom Runtime.description: A user-defined environment to run applications, often tailored for specific needs, platforms, or unique configurations.

Ballerina.description: An open-source programming language designed specifically for cloud-native, distributed applications and services.

Groovy.description: A dynamic, object-oriented programming language for the Java platform, frequently used for scripting and agile development.

Kotlin.description: A modern, statically typed language that runs on the JVM, often used as a more concise and expressive alternative to Java.

TypeScript.description: A superset of JavaScript that adds static types, improving development scalability, maintainability, and error prevention.

Open Source.description: Software for which the source code is freely available for anyone to view, modify, and distribute.

Proprietary.description: Software that is owned by an individual or a company, with the underlying source code typically not shared publicly.

Closed Source.description: Software whose source code is not openly available, or only accessible under restricted conditions.

Automatic.description: A process where computational resources and scaling adjust dynamically to demand without human intervention.

Manual.description: A process requiring human intervention, often to adjust computational resources or scaling based on demand.

Scaling Granularity (Per function).description: The capability of a serverless platform to automatically scale individual functions independently based on demand.

CLI.description: Command Line Interface, a text-based interface that allows users to interact with a system by typing commands.

API.description: Application Programming Interface, a set of rules and protocols that allow different software entities to communicate with each other.

GUI.description: Graphical User Interface, an interface that enables users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and visual indicators.

Web-Based Dashboard.description: An online graphical interface that allows users to monitor, manage, and configure serverless functions and resources.

Custom Interface.description: A user-defined interface that enables personalized interaction and control over serverless functions and workflows.

Scripting Language.description: A programming language used to write scripts for automating tasks, often in a serverless or configuration environment.

Kubernetes Integration.description: The ability of a serverless platform to work seamlessly with Kubernetes for container orchestration and management.

Execution Time.description: The total amount of time that a serverless function runs, often impacting billing based on usage duration.

Allocated Memory.description: The specified amount of memory assigned to a function, influencing billing based on the chosen allocation size.

Consumed Memory.description: The actual memory used by a function during execution, which may vary from allocated memory, and may affect costs.

Open source infrastructure cost only.description: A cost model where charges are limited to infrastructure resources, with no additional fees for open-source software usage.

1s - 15mints.description: The maximum duration a function is allowed to run, often capped between 1 second and 15 minutes for serverless functions.

1s - 9mints.description: A specified timeout limit for function execution, typically up to 9 minutes to prevent overuse of resources.

1s - 60mints.description: A broader timeout range allowing functions to run between 1 second and 60 minutes before being terminated.

Configurable Per Function.description: Customizable timeout settings allowing each function to have a unique execution limit based on specific needs.

250MB Uncompressed.description: The maximum size of an uncompressed package or deployment file allowed, often capped at 250MB.

50MB Compressed.description: The maximum size allowed for compressed deployment packages, typically up to 50MB to ensure efficient storage and transfer.

500MB Uncompressed.description: A larger limit for uncompressed packages, allowing deployments up to 500MB.

100MB compressed.description: A compressed package size limit of 100MB, supporting efficient storage and network transfer.

Configureable.description: An option that allows the package size limit to be adjusted based on specific needs or deployment constraints.

1029 MB - 10240MB.description: The range of memory allocation options, from 1028MB to 10,240MB, providing flexibility for different workloads.

129 MB - 8192MB.description: A memory range from 128MB to 8,192MB, enabling scalability for functions with varying resource needs.

128MB - 14336MB.description: Extended memory allocation options between 128MB and 14,336MB for resource-intensive functions.

128MB - 3072MB.description: Memory options ranging from 128MB to 3,072MB, often suitable for lightweight to medium-complexity tasks.

Configurable per action.description: Allows memory allocation to be specified individually for each action within a function, optimizing resource use.

Configurable per Function.description: Enables memory settings to be customized for each function, based on specific resource demands and cost constraints.

GDRP.description: General Data Protection Regulation, a European Union regulation aimed at protecting personal data and privacy of EU citizens.

HIPPA.description: U.S. legislation providing data privacy and security provisions for safeguarding medical information.

SOC.description: Service Organization Control standards, ensuring secure and privacy-focused management of data.

PCI.description: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard compliance, ensuring secure handling of credit card information.

DSS.description: Data Security Standard, ensuring comprehensive data protection and secure data handling practices.

ISO.description: International Organization for Standardization standards, ensuring quality, safety, and efficiency in business processes.

Depends on Underlying Platform.description: Indicates that compliance certifications or standards vary depending on the specific cloud provider or platform used.

Synchronous - 6MB.description: The maximum payload size allowed for synchronous requests, limited to 6MB to ensure efficiency and stability.

Synchronous - 10MB.description: The maximum payload size for synchronous requests, allowing up to 10MB of data to be processed in a single call.

Asynchronous - 256KB.description: The maximum payload size for asynchronous requests, capped at 256KB to optimize performance and scalability.

Asynchronous - 10MB.description: Allows asynchronous requests to handle payloads up to 10MB, suitable for larger data transfers.

Asynchronous - 100MB.description: The maximum payload size for asynchronous operations, permitting up to 100MB of data per request.

Limited by underlying platform.description: Indicates that the maximum payload size varies and depends on the specific cloud provider or platform’s limitations.

1000.description: Specifies a limit of 1,000 concurrent executions for serverless functions to manage resources effectively.

200.description: A limit of 200 concurrent executions, commonly imposed to maintain stability and performance in multi-function environments.

Configurable.description: Allows the maximum concurrent executions to be adjusted based on user-defined requirements or specific use cases.

Synchronous.description: A model where the caller waits for the function to complete and return a response before proceeding.

Asynchronous.description: A model where the caller invokes the function and continues without waiting for the function to complete.

Event source mapping.description: A mechanism to map and trigger serverless functions in response to events from sources like message queues or streams.

1million free requests.description: A usage plan offering 1 million free function requests, allowing users to explore the platform at no cost.

2million free requests.description: A usage plan offering 2 million free function requests, providing additional capacity without cost.

40K GB/month.description: A free tier plan allowing 40,000 GB of data processing per month without charge.

API Gateway.description: A service that provides a centralized entry point for APIs, managing requests and routing them to backend services or serverless functions.

Cloud endpoint.description: A service endpoint that allows interaction with cloud services, enabling application connectivity with other cloud resources.

Retries.description: Automated re-execution of failed functions to handle transient errors and improve application robustness.

Dead Letter Queue.description: A queue for storing messages or requests that cannot be processed successfully, allowing for later inspection and handling.

Error reporting.description: The process of capturing and logging errors, providing insights and data for debugging and improving functions.

Durable task Framework.description: A framework for managing long-running, stateful workflows in serverless applications, ensuring reliable execution of tasks.

Application insights.description: A monitoring service that provides performance, diagnostics, and usage data for applications, helping to identify and resolve issues.

VPC.description: A virtual network that isolates AWS resources in a dedicated section of the cloud for enhanced security and network control.

ENI.description: A virtual network interface that can be attached to an instance in a VPC, providing additional networking capabilities.

Subnet.description: A segment of a VPC’s IP address range where groups of resources can be isolated and organized.

Vnet Integration.description: Enables serverless functions to connect securely to a virtual network (VNet) in Azure, facilitating private communication.

Depends on Underlying platform.description: Indicates that networking configuration options may vary based on the specific cloud provider or platform used.

Custom DNS Configuration.description: Allows defining and using custom domain name system settings, improving access and management of serverless functions.

Private endpoint connectivity.description: Establishes a secure, private connection to serverless functions without exposing them to the public internet.

Memory.description: The allocated memory resources available to a function, which impacts performance and resource use.

CPU.description: The computing power allocated to a function, essential for handling processing needs efficiently.

Provisioned Concurrency.description: A feature allowing functions to be pre-warmed, ensuring low latency for immediate processing when invoked.

Dedicated Plans.description: Serverless plans that allocate dedicated resources for functions, providing predictable performance and cost management.

Cloud Endpoints.description: A cloud service that enables applications to securely connect and interact with other cloud services and external resources.

Docker.description: A platform that enables developers to build, ship, and run applications in isolated containers for consistency across environments.

Kubernetes.description: An open-source system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications across clusters.

Fully Managed.description: A cloud service where the provider manages infrastructure and maintenance, allowing users to focus on development.

IaC.description: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) is the practice of managing and provisioning computing infrastructure through machine-readable configuration files.

Kafka.description: A distributed event streaming platform commonly used for building real-time data pipelines and streaming applications.

NATS.description: A lightweight, high-performance messaging system for cloud-native applications, facilitating asynchronous communication.

RabbitMQ.description: An open-source message broker that originally implemented the AMQP protocol and now supports multiple messaging protocols for reliable message passing.

Redis.description: An in-memory data store used as a cache and message broker with support for pub/sub messaging patterns.

MNS.description: Alibaba Cloud's reliable message service for inter-application communication across cloud environments.

CMQ.description: Tencent Cloud's asynchronous messaging and communication service, supporting message queuing across distributed systems.

TDMQ.description: Tencent’s distributed message queue, designed for managing messaging in distributed systems and supporting a range of protocols.

Pub/Sub.description: A messaging pattern where publishers send messages to a broker, which then distributes them to subscribers.

Own Developed.description: Custom-built messaging solutions tailored for specific organizational needs, providing flexibility in messaging operations.

HTTP.description: A protocol used for client-server communication, commonly for simple message exchanges or trigger responses.

Cron.description: A scheduler that automates the running of scripts or tasks at specified intervals or times.

Cloud events.description: A standard for defining event data to facilitate interoperability across cloud services.

HTTP Triggers.description: Mechanisms that initiate functions in response to HTTP requests made to a specific URL endpoint.

CronJob Triggers.description: Scheduled triggers that execute functions at predefined intervals or times, specified using cron syntax.

Kafka Triggers.description: Triggers that start functions in response to messages or events published to an Apache Kafka topic.

NATS Triggers.description: Triggers that initiate functions based on messages or events transmitted through the NATS messaging system.

Async Trigger (Queue Trigger).description: Triggers that respond to messages placed in a queue, enabling asynchronous task processing without waiting for completion of previous tasks.

MQTT Trigger.description: Triggers that activate functions based on messages sent via the MQTT protocol, commonly used for IoT applications.

Custom Trigger.description: User-defined triggers that initiate functions based on specific, customizable conditions or events.

Timer Triggers.description: Triggers that execute functions based on a set timer or schedule, similar to cron jobs, but often with simpler configurations.

Kubernetes Watch Triggers.description: Triggers that initiate functions in response to events or changes within a Kubernetes environment, such as modifications to resources like pods.

Azure Event Hub.description: A highly scalable data streaming and event ingestion service from Microsoft Azure that can process millions of events per second.

Kinesis.description: AWS's platform for collecting, processing, and analyzing real-time streaming data, often used for data-intensive applications.

Unlimited.description: No limit on the number of functions that can be deployed within a serverless project, allowing unlimited scalability.

1001 per project.description: A restriction limiting the total number of functions to 1,000 within a single serverless project.

Cold start (Under few seconds).description: A function start mode where a new instance is created upon invocation, typically adding a few seconds of latency.

Warm start.description: A function start mode where an instance is pre-warmed and ready to respond, resulting in lower latency.

Function fusion.description: A technique where multiple functions are combined into one to optimize performance or reduce start-up overhead.

Functional testing.description: Testing that verifies if each function or system component behaves as expected under specified conditions with known inputs.

Non-functional Testing.description: Testing that evaluates aspects such as performance, reliability, and usability rather than specific functionalities.

Unit Testing.description: Testing individual components or functions in isolation to ensure they function correctly on their own.

Integration Testing.description: Testing combined components or modules as a group to identify interface or compatibility issues between them.

End-to-End testing.description: Testing that validates the complete functionality and flow of an application from start to finish, covering all systems and dependencies.

TLS Support.description: Support for the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol, enabling encrypted and secure data transmission over networks.

Integrated Security Model.description: A comprehensive security framework built into the system architecture to address aspects like authentication and data protection.

Code Signing.description: A security measure where code is digitally signed to ensure its integrity and confirm it hasn’t been tampered with.

Resource-Based Policies.description: Policies applied directly to resources, managing access and permissions based on specified rules and requirements.

Secrets Management.description: Tools and practices for securely managing sensitive data such as passwords and tokens within applications.

IAM Roles/Access Control.description: Mechanisms that define and enforce permissions for users and services, ensuring secure access to functions and resources.

Security Scanning.description: Automated inspections of serverless functions to detect vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, and compliance issues.

Fault Tolerance.description: The ability of a system to continue operating properly even when some of its components fail.

Load balancing.description: Distribution of workload across multiple resources to prevent overload and improve system reliability and responsiveness.

High throughput Computing.description: Computing that uses multiple resources over an extended period to accomplish large-scale or data-intensive tasks.

HA clustering & replication.description: High Availability (HA) techniques that use clusters and data replication to ensure uptime and prevent data loss.

Resilience.description: The capability of a system to quickly recover from disruptions or failures to ensure continuous operation.

Priority queue.description: A data structure that processes tasks based on priority, with high-priority items addressed before lower-priority ones.

EFS Integration.description: Integration with Amazon Elastic File System (EFS) for scalable, elastic file storage that serverless functions can access.

External Storage Providers.description: Support for integrating with third-party storage providers to extend data management and storage capacity.

Serverless Database.description: A managed database service that automatically scales without requiring infrastructure management by the user.

File System Access.description: The ability for serverless functions to read and write data to a file system, enabling persistent data storage and retrieval.

Performance prediction.description: Tools and techniques used to forecast system performance under varying conditions to aid in planning and optimization.

QoS.description: Quality of Service, referring to the overall performance of a network or system as perceived by the end users.

Function Composition.description: The ability to combine multiple serverless functions into a single workflow, enabling complex, modular processes.

Response streaming.description: A technique that sends data in a continuous flow, allowing clients to start processing the data as it arrives, even before the full response is complete.

Alerting.description: The system’s capability to monitor events and conditions, notifying users or administrators of significant events or anomalies that require attention.

Backup and restore.description: The process of creating copies of data to protect against loss or corruption, with the ability to restore data from backups as needed.

Log retention.description: The practice of storing logs for a defined period to ensure availability for future analysis, auditing, and troubleshooting.

Runtime Logging.description: Capturing and recording logs during the execution of serverless functions, providing insights into performance and behavior in real-time.

Tracing.description: A technique for tracking the flow and performance of requests across distributed systems, allowing identification of bottlenecks and issues.

Custom backend services.description: Tailor-made services that run in the background to support the primary functions of an application, often built to meet specific business requirements.

Third-party integration.description: The ability to connect and function with external services or applications, facilitating seamless interoperability and extended capabilities.

Built-in AI/ML integration.description: Features that support integration with artificial intelligence and machine learning services, enabling advanced capabilities like data analysis and automation.

Integration for data science tools.description: Support for data science tools, allowing seamless connectivity and functionality for analytics and operational processes within serverless applications.

Custom Logic Extensions.description: User-defined extensions that allow customization of serverless functions with specific behaviors or logic for unique use cases.

Relational Database Integration.description: The capability to connect and interact with relational database systems, facilitating data storage, retrieval, and manipulation.

Integration with Operational Tools.description: Allows serverless applications to connect with tools used for monitoring, management, and operational support.

Multiple function orchestration.description: Management and coordination of several functions working together to complete a workflow or process, enhancing modularity and reusability.

Custom integrations.description: Tailored connections between different software tools or platforms, built to fulfill specific business or technical needs.

Function Builder API.description: APIs that enable developers to create, configure, and manage serverless functions programmatically, simplifying development and automation.

Language Extensions.description: Additional libraries or tools that extend the capabilities of programming languages used in serverless functions, adding more functionality.

IoT Integration.description: The ability to connect and manage Internet of Things (IoT) devices within serverless architectures, enabling data collection and processing from IoT sources.

Serverless Framework support.description: Compatibility with the Serverless Framework, a tool that facilitates building, deploying, and managing serverless applications.

GraphQL support.description: Enables serverless applications to use GraphQL, a query language for APIs that allows flexible and efficient data querying and manipulation.

Data Sovereignty.description: The concept that digital data is subject to the laws and governance of the country in which it is located or stored.

Support for data-intensive applications.description: System capabilities that support applications requiring significant data processing, often with large datasets and complex computations.

Offline Usage.description: The ability of applications to function without an internet connection, allowing productivity in disconnected environments.

Datapipeline & ETL Jobs.description: Tools and processes for extracting, transforming, and loading data from various sources into a destination, typically for analysis or storage.

Caching.description: The practice of storing frequently accessed data in a temporary storage location to improve performance and reduce latency.

Global Function Invocation.description: The ability to invoke serverless functions from multiple geographic locations, ensuring low latency and high availability.

Function Dependencies.description: The management and inclusion of external libraries or services that serverless functions rely on to execute properly.

Function Import/Export.description: The capability to transfer serverless functions and their configurations between environments for easier deployment and management.

Event-driven.description: A programming paradigm in which functions or processes are triggered by specific events such as user actions or sensor outputs.

Scheduled Execution.description: The ability to execute a function or task at a predetermined time or on a recurring schedule, often managed through cloud-based schedulers.

Event Source Mapping.description: Configurations that allow applications to respond to events from specific sources, routing them to appropriate functions.

Event Bridge/Bus.description: A service that routes events from various sources to target destinations, enabling the creation of event-driven architectures.

Event Filtering.description: A capability that allows the system to process only specific events based on predefined criteria, ensuring only relevant events trigger actions.

Batched Event Processing.description: Groups multiple events for processing in a single execution to increase efficiency and throughput.

Webhook for finished work.description: A notification system that sends HTTP callbacks to specified URLs when a task is complete, allowing external systems to react to the event.

Resource pooling.description: The practice of managing and sharing resources among multiple users or clients to improve efficiency and resource allocation.

Control Over infrastructure.description: The degree of control an organization has over its IT infrastructure, allowing for tailored configurations and optimizations.

Shared Memory access.description: A memory management method allowing multiple hardware or software entities to access the same physical memory space.

Container Image Support.description: The ability to run applications as containerized images, which include the application code and dependencies in an isolated environment.

Execution Role Management.description: Managing permissions that define what actions and resources a function or service can access during execution.

Layer Support.description: The use of software layers to separate different types of code, configurations, or dependencies, making deployments more modular.

Environment Variables.description: Configurable settings used to define operational parameters for serverless functions, allowing customization without code changes.

Cluster Management.description: The process of managing a collection of interconnected nodes that work together to perform computing tasks in a coordinated way.

Decentralization.description: The distribution of functions, processes, or systems away from a central location or authority, often improving reliability and scalability.

Vendor Lock-In.description: A situation where a customer becomes dependent on a specific vendor for products or services, making it costly to switch providers.

Hybrid Deployment.description: An approach in which an organization uses a mix of on-premises, private cloud, and public cloud services for deployment flexibility.

Reserved Instance.description: A billing option where cloud resources are reserved in advance, typically at a lower rate compared to on-demand usage.

Multi-Cloud Support.description: The capability to deploy and manage serverless functions across multiple cloud providers, enhancing flexibility and redundancy.

Customizable Templates.description: Pre-defined templates that users can modify to meet specific requirements, commonly used for software configuration or deployment.

Zero Downtime Deployments.description: A deployment strategy that ensures new versions are launched without interrupting the availability of services to end users.

Immutable Infrastructure.description: An approach where servers and infrastructure are never modified after deployment; changes are made by deploying new instances.

Remote Debugging.description: The process of debugging a program running on a remote system, allowing developers to troubleshoot issues from a different location.

Local Debugging.description: Debugging a program on the same system where it is being developed or run, often allowing for faster testing and troubleshooting.

Telemetry API.description: An interface for collecting and transmitting data on system performance and operational metrics, aiding in monitoring and diagnostics.

Inline Code Editing.description: The capability to edit code directly within the deployment environment, typically through a web interface or integrated development environment (IDE).

Local Development.description: The process of building and testing software on a developer’s local machine, often with tools that simulate production environments.

Function Specialization.description: Optimizing functions for specific tasks or runtime conditions, improving performance by adapting function operation to fit its use case.

CI/CD Integration.description: The ability to seamlessly incorporate Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment pipelines, automating testing and deployment of code.

Developer Experience.description: The overall ease and efficiency with which developers can create, deploy, and manage functions, often enhanced by tools, documentation, and support.

Bring your own dependencies.description: The ability to include custom libraries and packages in functions, offering greater flexibility and control over the runtime environment.

Customer Code Extensions.description: The ability to extend serverless platforms with custom code, allowing for specialized use cases and enhanced functionality.

Popularity.description: Indicates the level of adoption and interest in the platform within the developer community.

Vendor Ecosystem Maturity.description: Represents the platform’s development, stability, and reliability based on its market presence and evolution.

Community Support.description: Indicates the size and activity of the platform’s user community, including forums, discussions, and open-source contributions.

Learning Curve.description: The ease or difficulty of learning how to use the platform effectively, often based on available resources and documentation.

Developers Availability.description: Reflects the availability of skilled developers familiar with the platform, easing staffing and project scalability.

Service Level Agreements (SLAs).description: Formal commitments on uptime, response time, and support that the platform offers, impacting service reliability and trustworthiness.

Amazon Lambda.url: A serverless computing service by Amazon Web Services (AWS) that allows developers to run code without provisioning or managing servers. (URL: aws.amazon.com)

Microsoft Azure Functions.url: A serverless compute service by Microsoft Azure that enables developers to execute code in response to events without managing infrastructure. (URL: azure.microsoft.com)

Google Cloud Functions.url: A lightweight, event-driven serverless compute platform by Google Cloud for creating single-purpose functions that respond to cloud events. (URL: cloud.google.com)

Alibaba Function Compute.url: A fully managed event-driven compute service by Alibaba Cloud, allowing serverless application deployment with automatic scaling. (URL: alibabacloud.com)

Tencent SCF (Serverless Cloud Function).url: A serverless execution environment by Tencent Cloud that allows code to run without provisioning servers, automatically scaling to meet demand. (URL: intl.cloud.tencent.com)

Apache OpenWhisk.url: An open-source, distributed serverless platform that executes functions in response to events, supporting multiple programming languages. (URL: openwhisk.apache.org)

OpenFaaS.url: An open-source framework for building serverless functions with Docker and Kubernetes, supporting multiple languages. (URL: openfaas.com)

OpenLambda.url: An open-source serverless computing project focused on enabling research and experimentation in serverless computing. (URL: github.com/open-lambda)

Kubeless.url: A Kubernetes-native serverless framework that uses Kubernetes resources to deploy code without managing infrastructure. (URL: kubeless.io)

Fission.url: An open-source serverless framework for Kubernetes with live-reloading, versioning, and rich trigger support. (URL: fission.io)

FuncX.url: A function-as-a-service platform optimized for scientific computing, enabling distributed execution of scientific workflows. (URL: funcx.org)

Iron.io.url: A serverless computing platform offering scalable, event-driven processing through IronWorker, supporting background tasks and data processing. (URL: iron.io)

Fn Project.url: An open-source, container-based serverless platform that can run on any cloud or on-premises, supporting multiple languages. (URL: fnproject.io)

Knative.url: An open-source Kubernetes-based platform that manages serverless workloads on Kubernetes, offering deployment and lifecycle management. (URL: knative.dev)

Nuclio.url: An open-source, high-performance serverless framework focused on real-time and high-throughput data processing. (URL: nuclio.io)

Up.url: A command-line tool for deploying serverless applications to AWS Lambda, simplifying deployment and management. (URL: up.docs.apex.sh)

Zappa.url: A Python framework for deploying serverless applications on AWS Lambda and API Gateway, enabling easy Python application deployment. (URL: zappa.io)

OSCAR.url: An open-source serverless platform designed for scientific applications, optimizing the execution of complex scientific workflows. (URL: github.com/oscar-system)
